body:
Thanks for the pull request, and welcome! The Rust team is excited to review your changes, and you should hear from @alexcrichton (or someone else) soon.

If any changes to this PR are deemed necessary, please add them as extra commits. This ensures that the reviewer can see what has changed since they last reviewed the code. Due to the way GitHub handles out-of-date commits, this should also make it reasonably obvious what issues have or haven't been addressed. Large or tricky changes may require several passes of review and changes.

Please see [the contribution instructions](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more information.
:scream_cat: :fireworks: :confetti_ball:
wtf github is censoring the two most important files because this PR is too epic.
Note to self: make sure that we don't actually guarantee the no-allocation property.
:tada: :tada: :tada:
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30325) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
Make tidy fixed, but it is really ugly. There is no pretty way to format a very long function signature under 100 characters.
Rebased.

I'm a little concerned about allocating on creation, is there any way around it?

Edit: I believe using an Option on the root is a small price to pay for allocation free creation.
Note that the PR description is incorrect in describing this as a regression; this has always been the case.
I see but the reasoning is the same. Adding an option around the root node adds a single highly predictable branch, it shouldn't add more than a nanosecond or two to the timings.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #29973) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
The old BTreeMap code seemed to allocate in `::new()` as well, calling `Node::make_leaf_root(6)`. Is there an allocation vs no allocation on empty change?
Oh, whoops - I misremembered the BTreeMap behavior. There is no allocation on empty change.
@gereeter You might want to take it out of the PR description then (as @bors would immortalize it).
@arthurprs your issue is orthogonal to this PR. Changing the map to use Option (or whatevs) can be done at a later date if desirable.
@Gankro fair enough

@gereeter needs rebase :(

Will start review once rebase is done (sorry I've been cleaning up some loose ends at home).
Rebased. I'm still working on figuring out the segfault, which is especially annoying because it isn't triggering in my simplified tests and isn't hitting any debug assertions.
Argh, Github is actually making it impossible to comment on the code!

I'm reviewing this on Reviewable.

Note to self: 

`Owned -> Mut`

Decoupling Lifetime and Mutability over 

`Ownership = Owned | Immut<'a> | Mut<'a>` 

has two benefits:
1. NodeRef<*, Mut> can always `(&mut self) -> &mut`
2. NodeRef<Borrow<'a>, *> can always `(self) -> &'a`

Otherwise, the two applicable impls would need to be selected manually and duplicated. However this makes everything just a bit more complicated. Alternatively, one could take the Ownership route and select subsets with trait dispatch (Ownership: Mutable; Ownership: Lifetime<'a>).

_[src/libcollections/btree/map.rs, line 82 [r2]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/rust-lang/rust/30426#-K6kPPGogIDNsidUx-GH:-K6l1q3aRiqMN8MMF9m5:-1040017781) ([raw file](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/75a21310acb645e8fdb6aed50118e5a4a68802d1/src/libcollections/btree/map.rs#L82)):_
Note: I don't like this impl that I wrote, for various reasons. First, it's ugly. Recursively cloning the root might fix this, but see below. Secondly, it doesn't clone all the keys in a node at once or all the values in a node at once. This is important, because for many keys/values, cloning a bunch of them in a row is just a `memcpy`, so we are losing performance. The one very important thing this impl has going for it is that it is written solely using safe APIs, which, among other things, ensures panic safety.

The first few attempts I made at implementing `clone`, including recursively clone the root, had to be killed because I realize they violated panic safety. This is probably because I was still trying to get common cases to optimize to a bunch of `memcpy`s.

Even not trying to hit that performance checkmark, there are a few slight complications with recursively cloning. The invariant for internal nodes is that they contain one more edge than key/value pair, which means that we have to hold off on inserting each key/value until we have built the edge that follows it - this is why I am using `create_chain`. However, if I'm not trying to get `memcpy`s (a goal I can set aside for a later PR), than recursively cloning seems simpler than what I have here (which suffers many of the same issues), so I wll switch to that.

Also, I just realized that `out_root` needs to be wrapped in a `BTreeMap` or else everything will be leaked upon panic.

Ah, yes, iterators. So, my pointers/handles/cursors into a `BTreeMap` have free reign to roam anywhere around the map. This means, however, that it is unsafe to have two mutable or owned handles into a `BTreeMap` at once. Unfortunately, that is exactly what a double ended iterator needs to do - we just manually make sure that we don't cross the ~~streams~~ handles.

Sadly, I don't see a way to get rid of this unsafety, even if I was given free reign to add even more type parameters to `NodeRef` - the front pointer needs to go right and the back pointer needs to go left, and the locations the two pointers could go are dynamically disjoint, not statically.

We could actually de-dupe this with another trait, something like `IterMethod`. This trait would have:
- An associated type for what `Item` is yielded.
- Associated types for the key, value, mutability, and borrowing status parameters to `NodeRef`.
- A function producing an `Item` from a reference to a `KV` handle. This would have to be unsafe, because running it twice could (in the `Mut` case) result in aliasing `&mut`s.
- A function for ascending a node. This would have to be unsafe because `deallocate_and_ascend` is unsafe.

I initially rejected this idea because I didn't think it would be much prettier, but I can try it if you'd like.

Two reasons:

First, this case comes up as a possibility in the implementation of `handle_underfull_node`, and so it was a choice between `unreachable!()` here or `unreachable!()`. Since `handle_underfull_node` is conceptually only dealing with a single node, I feel like it should have no "global" assumptions like "no nodes have empty parents"

Second, I plan to reuse `handle_underfull_node` when implementing `append` and `split_off`. Naively chopping a BTree in half or building one with no respect for underfull nodes from left to right leaves a whole chain or edge of possibly underfull nodes stretching from the root to the leaf. Unfortunately, this chain may include empty internal nodes.

_[src/libcollections/btree/node.rs, line 410 [r2]](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/rust-lang/rust/30426#-K6MaQ_Obqd4MGCetY3-:-K6lS8r0VvEH_wci6-os:-328049885) ([raw file](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/75a21310acb645e8fdb6aed50118e5a4a68802d1/src/libcollections/btree/node.rs#L410)):_
Yeah, I need to write a big scary comment as to why this is unsafe. Basically, since `NodeRef`s can `ascend`, you could reborrow a mutable reference then go up and swap out or kill the node you were originally pointing to. Then the reborrowed lifetime ends and you go back to the now dangling original pointer.

Incidentally, preventing this unsafety is one of my ideas for further safety improvements - basically, if you add another type parameter that controls whether a `NodeRef` is allowed to `ascend`, then you can just turn off the ability when calling `reborrow_mut` and avoid the unsafety.

It definitely is horribly brittle to incorrect type bounds (we exploit those to avoid runtime storage and checks everywhere), but I tried to not depend on too many global invariants - there are only two big ones, namely that depth remains constant everywhere and the there is one more edge than there are key/value pairs.

Whoops, didn't finish my earlier comment. I tried this earlier, and quickly realized that this causes you to lose a _lot_ of functionality - we can no longer write functions that take both `Mut` and `Owned`, including functions as basic as `as_leaf_mut`. Additionally, it is impossible to make something that takes `Borrowed` but doesn't care about mutability, like `into_slices`.

However, I was thinking about it again, and I realized that although this results in a lot of functions that are much less generic than they need to be, in particular excluding the possibility of doing any mutation whatsoever through an `Owned` node reference, we don't really use that generality. The only user of `Owned` is `IntoIter`, and `IntoIter` doesn't need to do any mutation. Therefore, since it only does theoretical harm, not practical harm, I'm implementing this.
